message.content: We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s symptoms and history of diabetes suggest diabetic neuropathy. Loss of sensations of pain and temperature over the dorsal and ventral sides of the feet and over the distal one-third of both legs is characteristic of damage to small-caliber, unmyelinated C fibers and thinly myelinated A-delta fibers, as seen in option (C).

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s symptoms and history of diabetes suggest diabetic neuropathy, which commonly affects Aδ and C fibers, responsible for sensations of pain and temperature. Aα and Aβ fibers are responsible for proprioception and touch, which are normal according to the examination findings. Aγ fibers are responsible for muscle tone and reflexes, which are also normal.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms, especially the burning pain and loss of sensation to pain and temperature, suggest the involvement of small-diameter nerve fibers which are Aδ and C fibers. A and B fibers are larger and transmit motor and proprioceptive signals. Aγ fibers are gamma motor neurons that innervate intrafusal fibers in muscle spindles, whereas Aδ fibers and C fibers are unmyelinated sensory fibers that transmit pain and temperature signals.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s history of diabetes mellitus suggests diabetic neuropathy. The loss of sensations of pain and temperature over the dorsal and ventral sides of the feet and over the distal one-third of both legs indicates involvement of small unmyelinated, C fibers and thinly myelinated, Aδ fibers. Option A includes large myelinated fibers and is responsible for proprioception and motor control, while option B includes motor and autonomic fibers. Option D includes small, myelinated fibers and motor fibers.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s symptoms, especially the loss of sensation of pain and temperature, suggest damage to the small nerve fibers. Among the options, only Aδ & C fibers are small nerve fibers responsible for sensations of pain and temperature. Aα & Aβ fibers are large myelinated fibers responsible for motor function and proprioception, while Aγ & B fibers are medium-sized and involved in reflex arcs. Aγ & C fibers are not commonly known to be involved in sensory functions.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s symptoms suggest diabetic neuropathy, and the loss of sensations of pain and temperature over the dorsal and ventral sides of the feet and legs is consistent with the involvement of Aδ and C fibers, which are small fibers responsible for pain and temperature sensation. Aα and Aβ fibers are large fibers responsible for proprioception and touch. Aγ and B fibers are mainly responsible for muscle tone and motor control.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The fact that the patient has diabetes mellitus and has skipped his oral antidiabetic medications suggests that he may have diabetic neuropathy. The loss of sensations of pain and temperature over the distal one-third of both legs and feet indicate the involvement of Aδ & C fibers, which are small-diameter unmyelinated nerve fibers that transmit pain and temperature sensations. Aα & Aβ fibers are large-diameter myelinated nerve fibers that transmit tactile and proprioceptive sensations. Aγ & B fibers are involved in the control of muscle tone and reflexes.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s symptoms, especially the burning pain and loss of sensation of pain and temperature, suggest damage to small myelinated Aδ and unmyelinated C fibers, which are responsible for pain and temperature sensation in the distal extremities. Option (A) refers to large myelinated fibers responsible for proprioception and motor function, (B) refers to fibers involved in muscle spindle function, and (D) refers to fibers involved in muscle contraction.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The loss of sensations of pain and temperature suggests that the most likely involvement is Aδ and C fibers, which are responsible for transmitting pain and temperature sensations. Option A involves large myelinated fibers responsible for proprioception and touch, option B involves fibers associated with muscle tone and motor function, and option D involves fibers associated with reflexes and muscle tone.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s symptoms suggest peripheral neuropathy, which is a common complication of diabetes mellitus. Loss of sensations of pain and temperature over the dorsal and ventral sides of the feet and over the distal one-third of both legs are characteristic of involvement of Aδ and C fibers. Aα and Aβ fibers are responsible for touch and proprioception, and Aγ and B fibers are involved in muscle function.
